Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from my mother: “How are you, beta? Call me when you’re free.” It’s Saturday, and I know she expects me to check in, to share the little details of my week. I type a quick reply, promising to call after my office function this afternoon. As I set my phone down, my mind shifts to the event. It’s a semi-formal gathering, and my colleagues have been talking about what they’ll wear—dresses, skirts, bright colors. I feel the familiar tug of anxiety. As a Muslim, I’m committed to dressing modestly, covering my arms and legs, and wearing a loose scarf. I want to fit in, to not draw attention, but I also want to honor my faith. My mother would want to hear about my day, to know I’m comfortable and happy, but I can’t tell her how nervous I am about standing out. I stare at my closet, torn between a long, loose dress and the more fitted outfit my friends suggested. My phone buzzes again—my mother, checking in. I feel the weight of both roles pressing on me, unsure which expectation to meet.
